clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Intraoperative Continuous Airway Pressure (CPAP) on the Inflammatory Response to One-lung Ventilation
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Intraoperative Continuous Airway Pressure (CPAP) on the Inflammatory Response of the Lung With Cancer Undergoing Lobectomy. A Randomised Placebo-controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This is a randomized placebo-controlled trial studying the effects of intraoperative continuous airway pressure (CPAP) on the inflammatory response of the lung with cancer undergoing lobectomy.

detailed_description.textblock: Pulmonary lobectomy induces an inflammatory response of this lung caused by intraoperative atelectasis and re-expansion. This inflammatory response can be attenuated with treatment, also decreasing postoperative pulmonary complications (PPC). Thus, avoiding complete atelectasis with partial insufflation of the lung during surgery could be useful to decrease inflammatory response and PPC.

primary_outcome.measure: Alveolar and plasmatic cytokines measured before and after atelectasis and re-expansion.
primary_outcome.description: Alveolar and plasmatic cytokines measured before and after atelectasis and re-expansion.

secondary_outcome.description: Alveolar MICA I (major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I chain related genes) expression measured at the same control times.
Postoperative distribution of well-aerated, non aerated or poorly aerated lung volumes.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 10 days.

arm_group.description: To evaluate if continuous positive airway pressure(CPAP) on the lung undergoing lobectomy can decrease the inflammatory response PPC (postoperative pulmonary complications).

intervention.description: To evaluate if continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on the lung undergoing lobectomy can decrease the inflammatory response and PPC.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults (18-80 aged) with American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status I-III, scheduled to undergo elective thoracic surgery with lung resection performed through thoracotomy, and requiring OLV (one lung ventilation)during surgery.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ongoing treatment with any dose of systemic or topical steroids, acute pulmonary or extrapulmonary infections (elevated C-reactive protein [CRP]), history of recurrent pneumothoraces, previous thoracic surgery.
